Euraba Band | current_members = | website = }} '''Roger Knox''' (born 1948) is an Australian [[Australian country music|country singer]], nicknamed "the Black Elvis" and "Koori King of Country". == Early life and education== Knox was born in 1948{{cite news|last1=Dickinson|first1=Chrissie|title=To Roger Knox, the whole world is country|url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/2013/02/19/to-roger-knox-the-whole-world-is-country/|access-date=20 December 2014|work=[[Chicago Tribune]] |date=19 February 2013}}{{cite news |last1=Guilliatt |first1=Richard |title=Songlines of a survivor: Roger Knox|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/features/songlines-of-a-survivor-roger-knox/story-e6frg8h6-1226658460268?nk=99ea51c9b54ba94d692634e3e6f404d8|accessdate=20 December 2014|work=[[The Australian]]|date=8 June 2013}} in [[Moree, New South Wales]]. He is of the [[Gamilaroi]] nation, an [[Aboriginal Australian]] people. Knox grew up in the [[Toomelah Station|Toomelah Aboriginal Mission]] near [[Boggabilla]], which is near the border between [[New South Wales]] and [[Queensland]].{{cite web |last1=Browning|first1=Daniel|title=Roger Knox – Koori King of Country|url=http://www.abc.net.au/rn/awaye/stories/2003/858423.htm |website=AWAYE!|publisher=[[ABC Radio National]]|accessdate=20 December 2014| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080531225401/http://abc.net.au/rn/awaye/stories/2003/858423.htm |archivedate=31 May 2008|date=23 May 2003}}{{cite news |last1=Kim |first1=Ignatius|title=Singing with something to say|url=http://www.greenleft.org.au/1993/103/6031 |accessdate=20 December 2014|work=[[Green Left Online]]|issue=103|date=9 June 1993 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080228232704/http://www.greenleft.org.au/1993/103/6031|archivedate=28 February 2008}} Knox comes from a family with 11 children. His mother was a [[Stolen Generations|stolen child]], who was taken from her parents as a baby and raised in a children's home in [[Bomaderry]]. Knox was not allowed to attend the high school in [[Goondiwindi]], but instead was sent by the mission to work without pay at one of their properties. Knox has said that the first music he heard growing up was [[gospel music]], which his grandmother, who taught [[Sunday school]], played.{{cite news|last1=Morrow|first1=Julian|title=Roger Knox: Stranger in my Land (video)|url=http://www.abc.net.au/radionational/programs/drive/roger-knox3a-stranger-in-my-land/4626386|accessdate=20 December 2014|work=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]] RN (Radio National) Drive|date=12 April 2013|format=video performance and interview}} == Career == Knox left the mission at 17 and moved to [[Tamworth, New South Wales|Tamworth]], where he became a singer. He started out in the 1980s as a gospel singer. He acquired the nickname "The Black Elvis" (for his hairstyle and manner of dress) at the [[Toyota Star Maker Quest|Star Maker]] talent contest when he was 31. He was also later dubbed "Koori King of Country".{{cite web|last=Leggett |first=Steve |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/roger-knox-mn0001624726 |title=Roger Knox – Biography |publisher=[[AllMusic]] |date=12 February 2013 |accessdate=21 March 2013}} In 2007, Knox went public with claims that he couldn't get booked at Tamworth's annual festival, [[Tamworth Country Music Festival]], "because he attracted the wrong crowd".{{cite news |last1=Grant |first1=Karla |author-link= Karla Grant|title=Living Black: Series 7, Episode 4|url=http://news.sbs.com.au/livingblack/series_7_episode_4_131666|accessdate=20 December 2014|work=[[Special Broadcasting Service]]|date=28 March 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090108122722/http://news.sbs.com.au/livingblack/series_7_episode_4_131666 |archivedate=8 January 2009|format=transcript}} === Jon Langford and the Pine Valley Cosmonauts/''Buried Country'' === On 12 February 2013, Knox along with the [[Pine Valley Cosmonauts]], released his first album in nine years, ''Stranger in My Land'' on [[Bloodshot Records]].{{cite web|last=Leggett |first=Steve |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/stranger-in-my-land-mw0002471493 |title=Stranger in My Land – Roger Knox, The Pine Valley Cosmonauts |publisher=[[AllMusic]] |date=12 February 2013 |accessdate=21 March 2013}} The album was produced by [[Jon Langford]] and included guest contributions from [[Bonnie "Prince" Billy]], [[Charlie Louvin]], [[Dave Alvin]] ([[X (American band)|X]], [[The Blasters]]), [[Kelly Hogan]], Jon Langford, [[Andre Williams (musician)|Andre Williams]], the [[Sadies]], [[Sally Timms]] ([[Mekons]]), and [[Tawny Newsome]].{{cite web|url=http://www.theworld.org/2013/02/aboriginal-roger-knox/ |title=Aboriginal Country Music from Roger Knox |last=Werman|first=Marco|work=[[PRI's The World]]|publisher=[[Public Radio International]]|format=audio interview |date=12 February 2013 |accessdate=21 March 2013}}{{cite news|title=Spotlighting Roger Knox: A week's worth of previews|url=http://nodepression.com/article/spotlighting-roger-knox-weeks-worth-previews|accessdate=20 December 2014|work=[[No Depression (magazine)|No Depression]]|date=31 January 2013}} The title of the record comes from a [[Vic Simms]] song.{{cite news|title=In The Studio With Roger Knox|url=http://www.deadlyvibe.com.au/2013/05/in-the-studio-with-roger-knox/|accessdate=20 December 2014|work=Deadly Vibe|date=23 May 2013}} Jon Langford illustrated the booklet that accompanies the CD. The material features covers of traditional and Aboriginal country songs. The record came about after Langford read about Knox in Australian author [[Clinton Walker]]'s book, ''[[Buried Country]],'' which chronicled Aboriginal country artists.{{cite web|last1=Walker|first1=Clinton|title=The Man Who Would be King: Roger Knox|url=http://www.versechorus.com/buried-country_roger-knox.html|website=Verse Chorus Press|accessdate=20 December 2014|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141107175624/http://versechorus.com/buried-country_roger-knox.html|archivedate=7 November 2014|df=dmy-all}} When Langford visited Australia, he heard many of the recordings, then went to see Knox play at Tamworth's annual country music festival. In 2009, Knox was scheduled to perform at the [[Old Town School of Folk Music]] (OTSFM) in [[Chicago, Illinois]], on 10 October 2009 with [[Jon Langford]] and the [[Pine Valley Cosmonauts]]. However, his US visa was denied a week before the show because the US immigration office stated he lacked cultural significance. The Knox-Langford tour finally occurred in 2012, including performances at OTSFM and the [[Hardly Strictly Bluegrass]] festival in [[San Francisco, California]]. In 2016, Knox joined the cast of the stage show adaptation of ''[[Buried Country]]'' itself, which played its premiere performance in Newcastle in August.{{citation needed|date=March 2019}} === Musical style === Describing his music, Knox says: "My music is basically country with an influence of aboriginal spirituality... I use all these (Aboriginal instruments such as [[didgeridoo]]s) but I still play country music. I may not sing about trains and sheep and cattle, but I still play country music". It has been described as "frequently upbeat and the lyrics often sharply political in tone. The lyrics are sprinkled with references to kangaroos and pelicans and detail the struggles of Australia's Indigenous Aboriginal population". ==Honours and awards== In 1993, Knox was named [[NAIDOC]] Artist of The Year.{{citation needed|date=March 2019}} In 2004, he was inducted into the Australian Country Music Foundation's Country Music Hands of Fame.{{cite web|title=Absent Friends-Roger Knox|url=http://www.deadlyvibe.com.au/2007/11/roger-knox/|website=Deadly Vibe|accessdate=20 December 2014|date=30 November 2007}} In 2006, Knox was given the [[Jimmy Little]] Award for Lifetime Achievement in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Music at the 2006 [[The Deadlys|Deadlys]].{{citation needed|date=March 2019}} == Activism == Knox is well known in Australia and is loved for his regular tours of the New South Wales and Queensland prison systems, where many Aboriginal men and women are incarcerated.{{cite news|last1=Corowa|first1=Miriam|title=Message Sick – Summer Series: Warrior in Chains|url=http://www.abc.net.au/tv/messagestick/stories/s2774829.htm|accessdate=20 December 2014|work=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]] Indigenous|date=10 January 2010}} Knox has also performed at many Canadian prisons for Native American prisoners. Knox participated in the Voices United for Harmony project, jointly managed by the Queensland Aboriginal and Islander Health Council and [[Griffith University]].{{cite news|last1=Strohfeldt|first1=Mahala|title=Indigenous voices unite for harmony|url=http://www.aiatsis.gov.au/koorimail/issues/pdf/488.pdf|accessdate=20 December 2014|work=The Koori Mail|date=3 November 2010|page=32|format=PDF}} == Personal life == ===Buddy Knox=== Knox's son Buddy is also a musician, starting to play guitar at the age of 10. In 2006, he formed the Buddy Knox Blues Band, which won Best New Blues Talent at the Australian Blues Music CHAIN Awards at Goulburn in February 2009. He was a finalist for Male Artist of the Year in the 2009 [[Deadly Awards|DeadlyAward]], and won numerous awards further awards. His debut album was ''got da blues'' (January 2008), which won the Newcastle Blues Awards Album of the Year.This was followed by ''Buddy's Blues'' in 2010, which comprises his own compositions as well as cover versions, including the National Musicoz Awards 2010 finalist "Squeaky Chair Blues". In 2011, he was nominated for a [[The Deadlys|Deadlys]] award. He has toured with the [[Warumpi Band]], [[Troy Cassar-Daley]], [[Paul Kelly (Australian musician)|Paul Kelly]], and [[Kev Carmody]].{{cite web|title=2011 Deadly Awards – Nominations: Male Artist of the Year – Buddy Knox|url=http://www.vibe.com.au/images/pdfs/deadly-awards-2011-mediakit.pdf |website=Deadly Vibe|accessdate=20 December 2014|page=10|format=PDF|date=15 July 2011}} Buddy married Sarina Andrew, daughter of famed Aboriginal country music singer [[Auriel Andrew]], but they later divorced.{{Cite web|url=http://www.noise11.com/news/r-i-p-auriel-andrew-1947-2017-20170102 |title=R.I.P. Auriel Andrew 1947–2017 |first=Paul| last=Cashmere |website=Noise11|date=2 January 2017 |access-date=5 January 2017| quote= Buried Country producer Mary Mihelakos has provided the following obituary by Clinton Walker| first2=Clinton| last2=Walker}} Their sons, Gene, John, and Ruben, played in Buddy's band at some point. ===Plane crashes=== Knox survived two consecutive aircraft crashes. In 1981, early in his career, Knox joined the roadshow of Brian Young, who had a band that criss-crossed Australia by light plane, which crashed due to engine failure. The musicians and equipment had to be airlifted from the crash site. The plane carrying Knox, drummer Ken Ramsay, and singer Stephen Bunz from the scene also crashed. Ramsay was killed and the others were injured (including the pilot). Knox suffered third-degree burns over more than 90 percent of his body and became addicted to painkillers. One of his [[Australian Aboriginal elder|elders]] prescribed a traditional [[bush medicine|bush remedy]] in the form of a natural bath oil made from the [[Eura bush]].
